Description: Rare X-linked disorder causing breakdown of myelin due to very-long-chain fatty acid buildup. Affects brain, adrenal glands, and nerves.

Disease_Name: Adult-Onset Leukoencephalopathy With Axonal Spheroids and Pigmented Glia (ALSP)
Description: Rare progressive white matter disease with cognitive decline, motor issues, and psychiatric symptoms. Caused by CSF1R gene mutations.
Group of progressive motor neuron diseases including Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).
Most common cause of dementia; progressive memory loss, confusion, and behavioral changes due to amyloid plaques and tau tangles.
Progressive degeneration of motor neurons leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, and death. Also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.
Genetic disorder causing developmental delay, severe speech impairment, ataxia, and inappropriate laughter. Due to UBE3A gene defect.
Impairment of language comprehension or expression due to brain damage (usually stroke).
Loss of coordination in voluntary movements, often due to cerebellar damage.
Spectrum of conditions with challenges in social interaction, communication, and repetitive behaviors.
Broad category including autism, intellectual disability, and developmental delays.
Disorders where immune system attacks nervous system (e.g., MS, Guillain-Barré).
Rare inherited disorder causing vision loss, seizures, and cognitive decline. Also called neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis.
Sudden weakness or paralysis of facial muscles, usually on one side. Often viral-triggered.
Tumors of the brain (glioma, meningioma) or peripheral nerves (schwannoma).
Bulge in brain artery wall that can rupture and cause hemorrhagic stroke.
Inherited small vessel disease causing strokes and dementia. NOTCH3 gene mutation.
Group of disorders affecting movement and posture due to early brain damage.
Damage to small brain arteries leading to cognitive decline and stroke.
Brain tissue extends into spinal canal. Causes headaches, balance issues.
Progressive degeneration from repeated head impacts. Seen in athletes and veterans.
Mild TBI causing temporary brain dysfunction. Symptoms: headache, confusion, memory issues.
Excess cortisol affecting brain function, mood, and cognition.
Umbrella term for cognitive decline severe enough to affect daily life (Alzheimer’s, vascular, Lewy body).
Malfunction of autonomic nervous system affecting heart rate, blood pressure, digestion.
Difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and relating them to letters.
Sustained muscle contractions causing twisting movements or abnormal postures.
Brain inflammation, usually viral. Causes fever, confusion, seizures.
Chronic disorder with recurrent unprovoked seizures.
Widespread pain, fatigue, cognitive issues. Central sensitization disorder.
Group of dementias affecting behavior, personality, and language (e.g., Pick’s disease).
Neurological symptoms (paralysis, seizures) without structural cause. Often stress-related.
Rapid-onset muscle weakness caused by immune attack on peripheral nerves.
Includes migraine, tension, cluster. Can be disabling.
Broad category of persistent head and body pain syndromes.
Inherited disorder causing progressive brain cell death. Symptoms: movement, cognitive, psychiatric.
Excess cerebrospinal fluid in brain causing pressure and cognitive issues.
Dementia with hallucinations, parkinsonism, and fluctuating cognition. Alpha-synuclein deposits.
Persistent rocking sensation after travel (boat, plane).
Inflammation of brain and spinal cord membranes. Bacterial or viral.
Recurrent severe headache with nausea, light sensitivity.
Includes Parkinson’s, essential tremor, dystonia, tics.
Progressive narrowing of brain arteries leading to stroke risk.
Immune attack on myelin causing fatigue, numbness, vision loss, mobility issues.
Group of 30+ genetic diseases causing progressive muscle weakness.
Muscle weakness worsening with activity. Affects eyes, face, throat.
Disorders caused by gene mutations affecting the nervous system.
Brain infections: encephalitis, meningitis, prion diseases.
Therapies to restore function after brain injury, stroke, or disease.
Sudden onset OCD and tics triggered by infections (streptococcus).
Progressive loss of dopamine cells causing tremor, stiffness, slowness.
Damage to peripheral nerves causing pain, numbness, weakness.
Persistent mental distress after trauma. Affects memory, mood, arousal.
Rare Parkinson-like disease with falls, eye movement issues, dementia.
Acting out vivid dreams due to lack of muscle atonia in REM sleep. Precursor to Parkinson’s.
Congenital brain malformation with clefts lined by gray matter.
Includes insomnia, sleep apnea, narcolepsy, RBD.
Progressive motor neuron loss leading to muscle weakness. SMA Type 1 most severe.
Rare disorder with muscle stiffness and painful spasms. GAD antibody positive.
Sudden interruption of blood to brain causing cell death. Ischemic or hemorrhagic.
Vitreous hemorrhage following subarachnoid hemorrhage.
Involuntary motor and vocal tics. Onset in childhood.
Mini-stroke with temporary symptoms. Warning sign of full stroke.
Brain damage from external force. Ranges from mild (concussion) to severe.
Rhythmic shaking. Includes essential tremor, Parkinsonian tremor.
